item.description:

Phillip Morris Study

(Cost/Benefit Analysis Smoking)

Philip Morris, the tobacco company, does huge business in the Czech Republic. They commissioned a cost-benefit analysis of smoking in the Czech Republic and found that the government allowing smoking could save money over the cost.

The Ford Pinto Case

It was in the 1970s. The Ford Pinto, a kind of car, had a problem, which is that the fuel tank was at the back of the car and in rear collisions, the fuel tank exploded and some people were killed and some severely injured. Victims of these injuries took Ford to court to sue.

In the court case, they found that Ford had long since known about the problem and had done a cost-benefit analysis to determine whether it would be worth it to put in a special shield that would protect the fuel tank and prevent it from exploding.

Discussion

Proposition to utilitarianism

  • There needs to be a number on human life because we need to make decisions somehow.
  • It’s for the general, for the greater good. Someone has to be traded off for the sake of utility.

Opposition to utilitarianism

  • The value to human life could not be assigned.
  • It failed to take account things on suffering and emotional losses of the victims' families.
  • It does not consider the effect on the minority.

Thorndike’s Study

It is possible to aggregate all values to translate them into dollar terms?

In the 1930s, Thorndike tried to prove what utilitarianism assumes, that it is possible to translate all goods, all values, into a single uniform measure, and he conducted a survey of young recipients of relief. He gave them a list of unpleasant experiences and asked them,

How much would you have to be paid to undergo the following experiences?

The conclusion of the study: Any want or a satisfaction which exists in some amount and is therefore measurable.

item.title: The Case of Cannibalism
item.description:
Zhengjian's Blog https://Zhengjian-L.github.io/posts/justice/2-the-case-of-cannibalism/ -

The Benthamite Utilitarianism

“Nature has placed mankind under the governance of two sovereign masters, pain and pleasure.” – Jeremy Bentham

With a lot of morally intuitive appeal, Bentham’s idea is the following, the right thing to do; the just thing to do is to maximize utility.

“The greatest good for the greatest number.”

The Queen v. Dudley and Stephens (1984) (The Lifeboat Case)

A brief overview of the case: Suppose you find yourself in a situation in which killing an innocent person is the only way to prevent many innocent people from dying. What’s the right thing to do? This question arose in The Queen v. Dudley and Stephens (1884), a famous English law case involving four men stranded in a lifeboat without food or water. How should we judge the action of Dudley and Stephens? Was it morally justified or morally wrong?

Discussion

The defense (It was morally justified)

  • There had no choice. You have to do what you have to do to survive.

  • If Dudley and Stevens had asked Richard Parker’s for his consent, it was morally justified.

  • Dudley and Stevens had family. They survived, therefore, the greatest utility is created.

The prosecution (It was morally wrong)

  • Taking others' fate or lives in your own hands is no allowed under any circumstances.

  • Even the consent of Parker would not justify their killing him, because cannibalism itself is immoral and is a way of not valuing others' lives.

  • There is not difference between lives.

Questions Raised

  1. Do we have certain fundamental rights?
  2. Does a fair procedure justify any result?
  3. What is the moral work of consent?

item.description:

Trolley Problem

The trolley problem is a thought experiment in ethics about a fictional scenario in which an onlooker has the choice to save 5 people in danger of being hit by a trolley, by diverting the trolley to kill just 1 person.

What would you choose, to divert it or not?

Moral Reasoning

  • Consequentialist 结果主义

Consequentialist locates morality in the consequences of an act.

The most influential example: Utilitarianism (a doctrine invented by Jeremy Bentham) 功利主义 边沁

  • Categorial 绝对主义

Categorical locates morality in certain duties and rights. The most important philosopher of categorical moral reasoning German philosopher Immanuel Kant(康德).
